sourcesContent:
import React, { useState } from 'react'; import { useProgress } from '../../contexts/ProgressContext'; const RelationalModel = () => { const { markTopicComplete } = useProgress(); const [completed, setCompleted] = useState(false); const [activeTab, setActiveTab] = useState('theory'); const tabs = [ { id: 'theory', name: 'Relational Model Theory' }, { id: 'keys', name: 'Types of Keys' }, { id: 'constraints', name: 'Constraints' }, { id: 'codd', name: "Codd's Rules" }, { id: 'examples', name: 'Solved Examples' } ]; return (

Relational Model in DBMS

Learn the fundamental concepts of the Relational Model, keys, constraints, and Codd's rules

{/* Tab Navigation */}
{tabs.map((tab) => ( ))}
{/* Relational Model Theory */} {activeTab === 'theory' && (

Introduction to Relational Model

Core Concepts:

  • Relation: A table with rows and columns
  • Tuple: A row in a table (represents an entity)
  • Attribute: A column in a table (represents entity property)
  • Domain: Set of allowable values for an attribute
  • Degree: Number of attributes in a relation
  • Cardinality: Number of tuples in a relation

Example STUDENT Relation:

ROLL_NO NAME ADDRESS PHONE AGE
1 RAM DELHI 9455123451 18
2 RAMESH GURGAON 9652431543 18

Degree = 5 attributes, Cardinality = 2 tuples

Key Terms:

Relation Schema

Defines structure: STUDENT(ROLL_NO, NAME, ADDRESS, PHONE, AGE)

Relation Instance

Current set of tuples at a particular time

NULL Values

Unknown or unavailable values, represented by NULL

Notation

R(A, A, ..., A) where R is relation name and A are attributes

)} {/* Types of Keys */} {activeTab === 'keys' && (

Types of Keys in Relational Model

Primary Key

Uniquely identifies each tuple in a relation. Must be unique and NOT NULL.

Example: ROLL_NO in STUDENT table

Candidate Key

Set of attributes that can uniquely identify a tuple. One candidate key becomes primary key.

Example: EMAIL, STUDENT_ID (both unique)

Foreign Key

Attribute that references the primary key of another relation to establish relationships.

Example: DEPARTMENT_ID referencing DEPARTMENTS table

Super Key

Set of attributes that can uniquely identify a tuple (may include unnecessary attributes).

Example: {`{ROLL_NO, NAME}`} or {`{ROLL_NO, ADDRESS}`}

Composite Key

Combination of two or more attributes that uniquely identify a tuple together.

Example: {`{STUDENT_ID, COURSE_ID}`} in ENROLLMENT table

Alternate Key

Candidate keys that are not chosen as primary key.

Example: If EMAIL is PK, then STUDENT_ID is alternate key

Key Properties:

  • Uniqueness: Each key value must be unique across all tuples
  • Minimality: No subset of a key can uniquely identify tuples (for candidate keys)
  • NOT NULL: Primary keys cannot contain NULL values
  • Referential Integrity: Foreign keys must reference valid primary key values
)} {/* Constraints */} {activeTab === 'constraints' && (

Constraints in Relational Model

1. Domain Constraints

Ensure each attribute value is atomic and comes from its specified domain.

Valid Data Types:

  • Numeric: INTEGER, FLOAT, DECIMAL
  • Character: CHAR, VARCHAR, TEXT
  • Boolean: TRUE/FALSE
  • Date/Time: DATE, TIME, TIMESTAMP

Example:

AGE must be INTEGER 0
PHONE must be numeric string
EMAIL must follow email format

2. Key Integrity Constraints

Every relation must have a primary key with unique, NOT NULL values.

STUDENT(ROLL_NO, NAME, AGE)
ROLL_NO is Primary Key
No two students can have same ROLL_NO
ROLL_NO cannot be NULL

3. Referential Integrity Constraints

Foreign key values must reference existing primary key values in parent table.

STUDENT Table:

ROLL_NO | NAME | BRANCH_CODE
1 | RAM | CS
2 | RAMESH | CS
3 | SUJIT | ECE

BRANCH Table:

BRANCH_CODE | BRANCH_NAME
CS | COMPUTER SCIENCE
ECE | ELECTRONICS
IT | INFORMATION TECH

Constraint: STUDENT.BRANCH_CODE must exist in BRANCH.BRANCH_CODE

4. Entity Integrity Constraint

Primary key attributes cannot accept NULL values.

Invalid: INSERT INTO STUDENT VALUES(NULL, 'John', 20)
Valid: INSERT INTO STUDENT VALUES(101, 'John', 20)
)} {/* Codd's Rules */} {activeTab === 'codd' && (

Codd's 12 Rules for Relational Database

Proposed by E.F. Codd, these rules define what constitutes a true relational database system.

Rule 1: Information Rule

All information must be represented as values in tables.

Rule 2: Guaranteed Access

Every data element must be accessible using table name, primary key, and column name.

Rule 3: Systematic Treatment of NULL

NULL values must be handled uniformly for missing information.

Rule 4: Active Online Catalog

Database catalog must be stored online and accessible using same query language.

Rule 5: Comprehensive Data Sublanguage

System must support a complete data manipulation language.

Rule 6: View Updating

All theoretically updatable views must be updatable by the system.

Rule 7: High-level Insert/Update/Delete

System must support set-level operations, not just record-level.

Rule 8: Physical Data Independence

Application programs should not be affected by physical storage changes.

Rule 9: Logical Data Independence

Application programs should not be affected by logical structure changes.

Rule 10: Integrity Independence

Integrity constraints must be specified separately and enforced automatically.

Rule 11: Distribution Independence

Distribution of data across locations should be transparent to users.

Rule 12: Non-subversion Rule

Low-level access should not bypass security and integrity constraints.

Importance of Codd's Rules:

  • Ensure data consistency and reliability
  • Provide standardized database behavior
  • Enable interoperability between systems
  • Guarantee data independence and security
  • Establish foundation for relational database theory
)} {/* Solved Examples */} {activeTab === 'examples' && (

Solved Examples

Example 1: Identifying Keys

Given a STUDENT table with attributes: ROLL_NO, NAME, EMAIL, PHONE, DEPARTMENT

Identify the types of keys:

  • Primary Key: ROLL_NO (unique identifier)
  • Candidate Keys: ROLL_NO, EMAIL (both unique)
  • Alternate Key: EMAIL (candidate key not chosen as PK)
  • Super Keys: {`{ROLL_NO, NAME}, {EMAIL, PHONE}, {ROLL_NO, NAME, EMAIL}`}

Example 2: Referential Integrity

Consider EMPLOYEE and DEPARTMENT tables:

EMPLOYEE Table:

EMP_ID | NAME | DEPT_ID
101 | John | D001
102 | Jane | D002
103 | Bob | D003

DEPARTMENT Table:

DEPT_ID | DEPT_NAME
D001 | HR
D002 | IT
D003 | Finance

Referential Integrity: EMPLOYEE.DEPT_ID must reference existing DEPARTMENT.DEPT_ID values

Example 3: Constraint Violations

Identify which operations would violate constraints:

Violation:

INSERT INTO STUDENT VALUES(1, 'John', NULL) - Primary key cannot be NULL

Violation:

INSERT INTO STUDENT VALUES(1, 'Jane', 20) - Duplicate primary key value

Violation:

INSERT INTO EMPLOYEE VALUES(104, 'Alice', 'D999') - Foreign key references non-existent department

)}
); }; export default RelationalModel;
